This makes the Friedman forecast an implausible joke of a forecast. He used economic multipliers that apply at relatively low growth rates and with slack labor demand, to a full employment scenario extended over a 10-year period. By 2016 year end, we will add another three million private sector jobs, and get within several million jobs of the all-time high employment level we hit at the end of the Clinton era.

Thats when Friedman's forecast period kicks in, and from this almost full employment scenario his forecast adds +35 million jobs over ten years, compared to 9 million the CBO used to match working age population growth + immigration. The other +26 million workers must come from the current population, even with accelerating retirements and more people in school. Friedman (and Sanders) are wrong with this unrealistic and unbelievable forecast of record high LFPR by 2026.We only get this LFPR if we use forced labor camps for elderly people.

The GDP growth estimates are worse... as we add marginal employees, Friedman forecasts a big acceleration in productivity growth. Bottom line, Krugman et.al. are correct, and Friedman/Sanders forecasts are off. The Rs will have an easy time ripping Sanders apart.
Yes, compared to the Trump plan, or the Cruz plan, Sanders' ideas will really do badly with voters... Oh wait, I just thought about that, and, huh... I'm not sure now.

Tell ya what, I'm looking at the 2009-present portion of that GDP per capita chart and I'm thinking, "Gee, if actual GDP growth were even half of what Friedman predicted that would be a huge improvement over current."  I'll say it again, if things turn out to be only half as good as Friedman predicts that will be a huge improvement over where we are now.  Show of hands, please - Who's got a problem with that?

The Galbraith letter cherry-picks the data, taking 3 years in the Reagan era to find GDP growth of 5.4%. It is not a 10-year sustained rate, as Friedman's analysis claims. (Reagan's 8-year average rate is 3.5%, before adjusting for a per-capita basis.) That is a huge difference. Galbraith's claim is, in fact, outlandish.

Dean Baker, a progressive economist who knows his numbers, calls Friedman's 5.3% rate "pretty hard to imagine" and he says "getting much over 2.5 percent growth on a sustained basis is pretty questionable."

http://www.vox.com/2016/2/18/11041838/bernienomics-wonks

This was a very interesting challenge to look at lying and the scenarios where it is acceptable or even required. The two that I struggle with being acceptable are 1 and 9. In both of these, it is lying out of convenience more than necessity really, and honesty should be preferred when there are alternatives.

In 1, I could honestly tell my wife that I will not tell her where we are going but she will enjoy it. If she persists, I have to honestly divert it. Avoiding having to deal with that engaement is where the lying comes in.

Nine was very similar in nature to me as 1. I could honestly tell the salesperson how much I was willing to pay. While the salesperson tried to edge that up, I would have to hold firm, no matter how minimal the increases seemed. To avoid that struggle, I lie to meet my original goal in an easier manner.

David Nyberg's defense of applied lying would support the Kennedy example in 6 as well as scenarios 2, 3, and 4. Nyberg views deception as an "essential component of our ability to organize and shape the world, to resolve problems of coordination among individuals who differ, to cope with uncertainty and pain, to be civil and to achieve privacy as needed, to survive as a species, and to flourish as persons" (qtd. in Johannesen et al, 2008).

Johannesen, R. L., Valde, K.S., & Whedbee, K.E. (01/2008). Ethics in Human Communication, 6th Edition. [VitalSource Bookshelf Online]. Retrieved from https://bookshelf.vitalsource.com/#/books/9781577669975/

DSM would you want your financial and banking information vulnerable to hacking? Of course not. However this is potentially why we are talking about. These days phones are so much more than a communication device. They are a repository of an individuals most import personal information. Financial data, passwords, very personal photos and videos etc. One just needs to look at the UK hacking scandal from few years ago to understand how dangerous it is not to have a very high level of encryption that not even Apple can hack without rewriting their OS.

There were innocent people killed and Apple is refusing to just open up this one phone and extract data? What if this phone contained information leading to future attacks. No one is asking apple to create a back door into their OS. It needs to extract data from one phone which they should be able to do. Claiming that they have to re-write entire OS or create a new OS is farfetched notion.
Funny Apple wants to make money in this country and yet shares no moral responsibility to help protect the very country where they live and prosper. There should be a mass boycott of apple products in this country and beyond.

Brett, the point you are missing is that no good capitalist is going to invest more money in his business or start a new company if he doesn't think he will get more customers to buy whatever it is he produces. In order for that to happen people must have money to buy whatever it is he produces. The problem is that people just do not. Wages have stagnated at best and too many are not working for various reasons.

That is why the money that rich people have IS either sitting idle in a bank vault somewhere or, more likely and even worse, being invested in financial speculation which does not help the economy and actually poses risks.

And Stephen please tell me where does money come from anyway?

Unfortunately for your theory, the Bush tax cuts did not show the results you're pointing to. The proposed stimulus would increase demand, and the rich will follow with increasing investment in the growing economy. Yes, hard to believe, they will have money left over after being taxed. And they won't sit on it, as they do now, if the economy is exploding with demand.
" The money that rich people have doesn't just sit idle in a bank vault somewhere."  -- Right now it does, and the evidence are the interest rates.

An increase in taxes on the rich stimulates the economy because it puts the money into the hands of those not-rich, who spend it. I gather there is relatively little dispute about this?

The argument about longer-term consequences is subtle, and I have heard no discussion about that at all. The question is whether whatever the government taking the increased taxes uses the money to do is more productive (as an investment) than the wealthy would have been if they'd not had it taxed away from them.

Looking at what the wealthy have accomplished with the Bush tax cuts, I'd say the argument is on the socialist side.
Yes, good point.  1,000,000,000 people, all fooled.  It couldn't be that Apple actually makes better phones, writes better software, and backs up its customers with actions, could it?
I can't speak to what most people would go for, but if I was a terrorist, drug dealer, corrupt banker, or celebrity stalker, I know what model I'd buy!

Here's a thought - FBI (Government) and Apple (Corporations) should let the people (Free Market) decide.
Apple can make two types of phones. One, let's call it iPhone-S (S for secure,) with full encryption. And another, let's call it iPhone-N (N for non-secure) with no encryption and free for federal agencies to get into and browse.
It will be interesting to see how many, including those who advocate that Apple should allow the government to hack into iPhones, will go for the N model?
